items.title: Review, A Visualization Player
items.details: Description: [Review](https://review.github.io/) is a web-based platform for sharing dynamic visualizations. [Code](https://github.com/review/review.github.io), [Description](/pdf/Clark.2018.EvoSoft.Review.pdf)

items.title: Evolve-a-Robot, An Online Evolutionary Robotics Environment
items.details: Description: [Evolve-a-Robot](http://evolve-a-robot.github.io/) is an interactive evolutionary robotics simulation. The project has two goals. The first is to expose K-12 students to evolution and evolutionary computation using an engaging and fun platform. Evolve-a-Robot does this by visualizing the evolution of robotic cars with an easy-to-use interface. And second, to expose enough of the adjustable parameters (i.e. genetic operators, and evolutionary configuration) to make the simulation useful for teaching evolutionary algorithms to undergraduate students. [Code](https://github.com/evolve-a-robot/evolve-a-robot.github.io), [Description](/pdf/Moore.2014.ALIFE.Web.pdf)

items.title: B.S. in Computer Engineering
items.organization: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kansas State University
items.details: Graduated magna cum laude

items.title: STEMentors Program Advisor
items.details: Advise the new outreach program, which is directed at providing mentoring for local lower-income schools.

items.title: Robotics Club Advisor
items.details: Given strong student demand, I (and one of our EE faculty) initiated Missouri State University's first robotics club.

items.title: CSC Representative, CNAS College Council (elected)
items.details: Act upon curricular matters that are referred to it by departments within the college. The College Council approves departmental proposals, rejects and returns proposals to the originating department, or amends and approves proposals.

items.title: CSC Representative, CNAS Student Recruitment Committee
items.details: Attend recruitment events on the behalf of the college, and make recommendations to the dean regarding recruitment procedures.

items.title: CSC Representative, CNAS Diversity Committee
items.details: Represent my department at the college level diversity committee. A primary goal for the members of this committee is to improve the retention of students that are considered at risk for either dropping out or transferring. We improve retention through a variety of activities: poster sessions, scholarships, and picnics.

items.title: ACM Chapter Advisor
items.details: Coordinate ACM study chapter activities, include: scheduling speakers, organizing off-campus activities (e.g., competitions), and recruit volunteers to help at departmental events.

items.title: Proactive Advisor
items.details: Attend special training sessions on proactive advising techniques so that I can better advise first generation computer science undergraduates. I currently advise ~75 CS students.

items.title: Coordinator, Computer Science and Engineering Graduate Association (elected)
items.details: Coordinated monthly meetings for graduate students in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, facilitated communication of Department news and policies, and organized graduate student service opportunities.

items.title: Graduate Representative, Computer Science and Engineering Graduate Studies and Research Committee (elected)
items.details: Act as a voting member of the GSRC, which establishes academic standards, coordinates graduate course offerings, determines admission standards and policies for financial awards, and evaluates Ph.D. qualifier examinations.

items.title: Graduate Representative, Computer Science and Engineering Departmental Meetings (elected)
items.details: Act as a voting member at CSE department meetings.

items.title: Officer, Eta Kappa Nu, Electrical and Computer Engineering at Kansas State University (elected)
First Lego League Team Mentor and Competition Judge
items.organization: FIRST
items.details: Responsibilities: Mentor one FLL team and judge at a regional competition.

items.title: Advising Undergraduate and Graduate Researchers
items.organization: Missouri State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Coordinate and advise from three to six undergraduate and graduate students from different departments every semester.

items.title: Instructor, Introduction to Evolutionary Robotics
items.organization: Introduction to Robotics Engineering Program, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Presented my research and an explanation of evolutionary robotics to 22 high school students. I introduced a web-based evolutionary robotics simulation platform (BoxCar2D) to the students and in a hands-on laboratory session helped them answer several questions regarding the evolutionary robotics process.

items.title: Mentor, Visiting Scholar Program
items.organization: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Co-mentored Mr. René Draschwandtner, a visiting Master's student from the University of Applied Sciences in Austria. I worked with Mr. Draschwandtner, Dr. Jared Moore, and Dr. Philip McKinley to study locomotion and grasping behaviors for a snake-like robot using methods from evolutionary robotics.

items.title: Presenter, 3D Printing Showcase
items.organization: Michigan State University Library
items.details: Responsibilities: Presented 3D printing technologies and my lab's research as part of outreach directed at undergraduates and the general public.

items.title: Co-Organizer of Sandbox Session, Evolution-In-Action Software and the Web
items.organization: NSF BEACON Center
items.details: Responsibilities: Organized an open discussion regarding the application of state-of-the-art web technologies to evolutionary research and outreach projects.

items.title: Instructor, BEACON High School Summer Residential Program
items.organization: W.K. Kellogg Biological Station, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Presented an overview of evolutionary computation to a group of four high school students interested in STEM fields, and then facilitated their work as they conducted, wrote about, and presented results from their own evolutionary study in a day-long course.

items.title: Mentor, NSF Research Experience for Teachers Summer Program
items.organization: College of Engineering, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Mentored a local high school engineering instructor, Charles Payson. Over the course of his second summer in the program, Mr. Payson designed, implemented, and presented a web application used to teach evolutionary robotics concepts to K-12 students and the general public. I taught Mr. Payson web-programming skills as well as aided him in developing a curriculum for high school students.

items.title: Instructor, Introduction to Robotics Engineering
items.organization: College of Engineering High School Summer Program, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Introduced evolutionary robotics to approximately 20 high school students in a tutorial style. The tutorial was based on an interactive web-based simulation environment developed by myself and Jared M. Moore. Students conducted evolutionary experiments in which they evolved robots in simulation.

items.title: Graduate Student Evaluator
items.organization: Undergraduate Research and Arts Forum, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Provided feedback to undergraduates presenting their research, and scored poster presentations for a competition.

items.title: Mentor, NSF Research Experience for Teachers Summer Program
items.organization: College of Engineering, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Mentored a local high school engineering instructor, Charles Payson. During a six-week program, I aided Mr. Payson in learning C++ programming, evolutionary algorithm development, and creating dynamic simulations. At the end of the program, I assisted Mr. Payson in translating his research into a robotics lesson plan using the VEX robotics platform.

items.title: Mentor, NSF Research Experience for Teachers Summer Program
items.organization: College of Engineering, Michigan State University
items.details: Responsibilities: Mentored a local elementary school teacher, Adam Ford, who specializes in computers and robotics. Mr. Ford developed the Biolume environment, which demonstrates evolution 'in-action' using using simple robots. The Biolume project is an outreach exhibit aimed at demonstrating evolutionary principles to the general public.

items.title: Assistant Professor of Computer Science
items.organization: Department of Computer Science, Missouri State University
items.details:
***Research Interests:*** autonomous mobile robots • evolutionary computation • machine learning
***Undergraduate Courses:*** algorithms and data structures • languages and machines • senior seminar
***Graduate Courses:*** evolutionary computation • deep learning • advanced robotics

items.title: Computer Science Teaching Assistant
items.organization: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Michigan State University
items.details:
Administered two lab sections of Introduction to Programming II (CSE232).
- approximately 25 students in each lab section
- covering lecture and lab material at the beginning of each session
- creating projects
- grading course projects (11 total projects)
- answering questions during weekly help-room sessions

items.title: Computer Science Instructor
items.organization: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Michigan State University
items.details:
Organized and taught Introduction to Programming II (CSE232) during the summer session.
- 56 students
- develop and present lectures covering introductory programming concepts using C++
- develop a series of course projects
- mentor and coordinate three teaching assistants
- modify and expand weekly laboratory assignments

items.title: Graduate Fellow and Research Assistant
items.organization: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Michigan State University
items.details:
Addressed optimization, adaptive control, and fabrication of bio-inspired mobile robotic systems.
- apply evolutionary algorithms to the design and control of mobile robots,
- design 3D-printed robots containing flexible components,
- work on an interdisciplinary team including engineers and biologists, and
- present research at the BEACON Center, an NSF Science and Technology Center.

items.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant
items.organization: Autonomous Vehicle Systems Laboratory, Kansas State University
items.details: Designed software used to capture images at specified GPS locations with an autonomous aerial vehicle.

items.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant
items.organization: Independent Research with Professor Stewart E. Stanton, Kansas State University
items.details: Investigated the fundamentals of convergence of complex solutions in power systems.

items.title: Software Engineer, Intern
items.organization: Department of Positioning and Sensors, Garmin International
items.details: Solved problems associated with positioning error due to antenna performance.

items.title: Undergraduate Research Fellow
items.organization: Data Science Summer Institute, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
items.details: Attended lectures covering the fundamentals of data science and worked on a team to create a reverse image search engine.

items.title: SAS Tutor
items.organization: Scholars Assisting Scholars (SAS) Program, Kansas State University
items.details: Attended lectures on the subject I was tutoring, provided walk-in, free tutoring consistent with course instruction, and led review sessions prior to exams.
